thread.title: 205 Pop Culture References in "Gilmore Girls"
thread.title_full: 205 Pop Culture References in "Gilmore Girls"

posts.title: 205 Pop Culture References in "Gilmore Girls"
posts.text: 205 Pop Culture References in "Gilmore Girls" Lauren Hoffman Photo credit: Netflix / Getty More Pop culture references are a hallmark of Gilmore Girls dialogue, and the revival was chock full of them, ranging from modern to classic to sometimes completely random examples. Here, 208 for your perusal. How many did we miss? When Rory takes over editorial duties of the Stars Hollow Gazette , she commissions a film review from Doyle. He sends back 20,000 words, 5,000 of which are adjectives. When she tries to tell him this won't work, Doyle shoots back that he's been working with director Michael Bay , and Michael LOVES adjectives. In the last moments of the final episode, Rory's childhood crushes are revealed to be Pee-Wee Herman , Edward Scissorhands , and Law & Order 's Jerry Orbach . Lorelai struggles throughout the series to come up with a sweet, touching memory of her father. Finally, she remembers a terrible day in her adolescence on which her dad cheered her up by taking her to see first Grease , and then An Unmarried Woman - a movie for each of them, by his logic. Kirk's short film about the death of his pig is bizarre on every level, but it's made even stranger by the fact that it's underscored by the orchestral theme from the classic tearjerker Terms of Endearment . As a part of her grieving process, Emily discovers Marie Kondo and The Life-Changing Magic of Tidying Up . This means that, among other things, Emily discards a ball gown, a bunch of Rory's stored boxes, and her dining room chairs, because they don't "spark joy" in her. When we first meet Paris again, she's in the middle of firing and browbeating a young woman who's a recent Smith graduate. In the process of laying her off, Paris taunts her for wasting two full semesters studying Buffy, the Vampire Slayer . Luke asks Lorelai what she's doing one night before bed, and she informs him that she's arranging her magazines by Kardashian . In her grief, Emily accidentally commissions a portrait of Richard that reaches from floor to ceiling in her living room. It's so formidable that Lorelei likens it to Gandalf from Lord of the Rings saying, "You shall not pass!" Moping over the Dragonfly's failure to attract a-list guests, Lorelai complains to Rory, "Why can't we bag Jennifer Lawrence ?" When picking bridesmaid dress themes, Lorelai offers Rory two choices: cult camp film The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert or D esnudas , body-painted street performers. After Luke's list of wedding guests looks a little paltry, Lorelai tries to get him to name someone - anyone at all - to add to it. In this exchange, it comes out that Luke is buddies with Kiefer Sutherland . Yes, that Kiefer Sutherland. 24 jokes abound. (They met at baseball camp.) During the writing of the Stars Hollow musical, Taylor claims he studied under Edward Albee , who wrote Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf? In this case studied = left a script on his table at a restaurant once, but STILL. When Emily reveals she has a new boyfriend (kind of) who is just as rich as she is, Lorelai twice quotes Kanye West's "Gold Digger." After Logan takes her on a debaucherous night around the countryside of New England, accompanied by some of their wildest college friends, Rory thanks him for taking her on her own private Mr. Toad's Wild Ride , from The Wind in the Willows (and, more important, from Disneyland). Lorelai insists that the fictional diner owner in A History of Violence is so similar to Luke that director David Cronenberg must have based him on Luke himself. There's a running gag in which the lead of the town musical (Sutton Foster!) played the character of Kinky Boots in the musical Kinky Boots . The joke is that that's what the musical is called, but there's no character of that name. (It is a VERY EXTENDED joke.) Among the personal effects at Richard's grave are a copy of Walt Whitman's Leaves of Grass and a Chuck Berry album. When Taylor announces he's planning a gay pride parade for Stars Hollow, his rationale for doing so in 2016 is that it coincides with the anniversary of a seminal Liza Minelli album. At dinner with April, Lorelai quotes a Woody Allen joke from Annie Hall : “I was thrown out of college for cheating on the metaphysics exam; I looked into the soul of the boy sitting next to me.” Lorelai only has one piece of advice for Rory about her manuscript about her lives, which she's titled The Gilmore Girls . "Drop the 'the.'" This seems like a direct reference to Sean Parker telling Zuckerberg to drop "the" from Facebook in The Social Network . Lorelai reads Wild , which leads her to buy a backpack and hiking boots and follow in Cheryl Strayed's footsteps. At the trailhead, there's a running joke about whether the scores of women there are "book people" or "movie people," depending on whether the memoir or its adaptation inspired them. While trying to get Rory interested in the idea of screenwriting, Doyle sends her DVDs of the Debra Messing series The Mysteries of Laura . Jess comes to visit Rory at her newspaper office, and she pulls a bottle of scotch out of the desk and pours him a drink for "lunch." He compares her to Lou Grant , the gruff newsroom boss from The Mary Tyler Moore Show . After Rory gets off a plane, Lorelai thinks she looks entirely too fresh-faced, and should look more like she should "be singing 'I Dreamed a Dream' with a bad haircut ," a nod to Anne Hathaway's Les Misérables performance. While trying to get the Stars Hollow Gazette 's ancient computer system to work, Rory notes that she should've paid closer attention to Halt and Catch Fire , the AMC series about the history of personal computers. posts.title: Netflix Looks Ripe for Downside Play
posts.text:
Netflix Looks Ripe for Downside Play By Timothy Collins | Nov 28, 2016 | 10:37 AM EST 
One name I don't see as a huge benefactor from the holidays is Netflix (NFLX) . While it may be on a few wish lists, I doubt it is something in high demand. I view Netflix more as a lifestyle change or rebellion move against cable, not so much as a gift. The stock saw a huge lift from earnings, but we've begun to wane, and a break of $115 should accelerate a move lower by $5 to $10. Factor in the short-term overbought market conditions and I'm looking at a downside play here. 
The weekly chart is still bullish in terms of price. Again, it's that $115 support level; however, there are cracks in the foundation. We have a bearish crossover in the Full Stochastics as well as the Chaikan Oscillator. This double-cross, especially after the Full Stochastics were recently over 80, has been fairly bearish. At worst, it should hinder further upside moves. My approach here is long the December 16 $115-110 put spread for $1.54....147

posts.title: Netflix December 2016: What's coming and going
posts.text:
Netflix December 2016: What's coming and going Get ready for seconds of Bob Ross and Chill. And lots more stuff. It's all good. By Scott T. Smith | Updated Nov. 28, 2016 at 1:13 PM Comments 1 of 2 
Sure, you've got mashed 'taters for Thanksgiving, and probably for a few days after. But if you want some of them French-fried 'taters a la Sling Blade on the Netflix, you're running out of time. MMMM- hmmm . 
That movie, featuring a mentally challenged adult man fascinatingly portrayed by Billy Bob Thornton , has an impressive 96 percent "Fresh" rating on Rotten Tomatoes. Your writer highly recommends it, but stream it before it vanishes at the end of November. Bonus: See if you can find the original short, called Some Call It a Sling Blade featuring Thornton with J.T. Walsh and Molly Ringwald , who did not appear in the full-length feature. Thornton wrote the short, and the full-length adapted screenplay that the short pitched to Hollywood. He took home an Oscar for his writing and a nomination for his acting. 
As Karl might say: "Aight, den" ... on to a couple more highlights from December's comings and goings in Netflix's video treasure trove (full list below): 
Love Kevin Spacey ? You'll cringe with his character in American Beauty ( 88 percent Fresh ) but hurry because it's gone Dec. 1. If you're into extreme sports, athletes who take incredible risks and/or need a good cry before the end of the month, might we suggest McConkey , a critically acclaimed documentary on extreme sports pioneer Shane McConkey. Try to figure out who's on top in "Top Gun" before it runs out of fuel on Dec. 1. 
With the family all home to argue about the election, you might consider The In-Laws a good distraction from the inevitable. Think again . This isn't the 1979 version starring Peter Falk and Alan Arkin . There's never enough Falk and Arkin – ever. The remake does have Albert Brooks, so there's that. After Dec. 1, you won't have to worry about it any more – on Netflix, anyway. 
If you just KNOW the government is hiding something really big via coded messages known only to the Illuminati, you have until Dec. 14 to find out – that's when The Da Vinci Code disappears like so much invisible continental congressional ink. 
Don't fret the losses ... a lot of cool new stuff is being added starting Dec. 1, including TOGA!!!! – National Lampoon's Animal House . And you'll be able to Netflix and Chill with Bob Ross to a greater degree than ever before ... featuring a collection of the big-haired painter's best, plus more than a few happy little trees starting bright and early Dec. 1. 
A slew of Netflix Originals are being added as well in December. Top of that list to watch with your Facebook-fake-news-sharing uncle is Barry , a biopic about Barack Obama that arrives on Dec. 16. Perhaps not. Possible alternatives from the newly arriving list include The Way of the Dragon , the awesome 1972 kung fu flick that features Bruce Lee denuding Chuck Norris ' chest of hair before dispatching him ... or perhaps Hitler: A Career ? Both arrive on Dec. 1. There's always America's biggest patriot beating up bad dudes in Marvel's Captain America: Civil War – arriving as a big present from Netflix on Christmas Day. Maybe just put your uncle on a filter and play it safe with My Little Pony: Friendship Is Magic: Season 6 , arriving Dec. 20. 
Here's the full rundown: Departing Netflix in December 2016

posts.title: Netflix's 'White Rabbit Project' looks like 'Mythbusters 2.0'
posts.text:
share Netflix's 'White Rabbit Project' looks like 'Mythbusters 2.0' Catch the first glimpse of 'Mythbusters' alums Kari Byron, Tory Belleci and Grant Imahara in their new science-based investigation series. Share Save 
White Rabbit Project isn't an official continuation of the Mythbusters franchise, but it's pretty darn close. The show stars former Mythbusters members Kari Byron, Tory Belleci and Grant Imahara, and it's set to premiere on Netflix on December 9th. This time around, Byron, Belleci and Imahara aren't just investigating strange scientific phenomena or seemingly impossible movie scenes; they're ranking history's weirdest inventions, heists and happenings, and seeing how science makes them possible. 
In its first trailer, White Rabbit Project shows off a few familiar Mythbusters tropes, including explosions, wacky robotics, big guns and mild torture in the name of science. There's everything from training pigeons to robot jousting, and even an attempt to eat a fancy meal with electrodes intermittently zapping the hosts' muscles. 
We first heard about White Rabbit Project in September. All episodes of the show will hit Netflix at once on December 9th.

thread.title: Netflix Releases Home Invasion Horror, ‘Mercy’
thread.title_full: Netflix Releases Home Invasion Horror, ‘Mercy’

posts.author: Brad Miska
posts.title: Netflix Releases Home Invasion Horror, ‘Mercy’
posts.text:
Netflix has just released Mercy , which Chris Sparling — who penned the 2010 Ryan Reynolds thriller Buried and Gus Van Sant’s The Sea of Trees — wrote and directed.
“Mad Men’s” James Wolk and “Master of Sex’s” Caitlin FitzGerald star in the home invasion thriller, which we reviewed out of the Los Angeles Film Festival earlier this year.
“ When four estranged brothers return home to say their last goodbye to their dying mother, Grace, hidden motivations reveal themselves. The family’s already tenuous bonds are tested when secrets from Grace’s past resurface, causing a restless night to go terribly awry as the brothers are thrust into a fight for their own survival. ”
Tom Lipinski (“The Knick”), Michael Godere (“The Affair”) and Dan Ziskie (“House of Cards”) also star in the film, which is produced by XYZ Films’ Kyle Franke and Nick Spicer and Uncorked Productions’ Andrew D. Corkin along with Robyn Bennett.
